webTitle: Low interest rates enter sixth year

fields.standfirst: Bank of England MPC maintains interest rates at 0.5% and leaves quantitative easing unchanged at £375bn
fields.body:
Interest rates have officially been on hold at a record low of 0.5% for five years, after Bank of England policymakers persisted with ultra-loose policy on the fifth anniversary of its dramatic move to limit the impact of the financial crisis.

The Bank's monetary policy committee also voted to leave its stock of asset purchases under quantitative easing (QE) unchanged at £375bn.

Policymakers at Threadneedle Street first slashed rates from 1% to 0.5% in March 2009, which was the lowest since the Bank was established in 1694.

In the same month it established its QE programme, with an initial £75bn of asset purchases. This was an unprecedented move to stimulate spending and ease the crisis in the financial markets, which had worsened with the collapse of Lehman Brothers in September 2008. The Bank focused QE on buying up government bonds in the secondary market, and steadily increased its spending to £375bn.

David Kern, chief economist at the British Chambers of Commerce, said on Thursday that the MPC must not be tempted to raise rates any time soon, despite an improved economic backdrop.

"The continued clamour for early rate rises is unwelcome and undermines the benefits of forward guidance to business, consumers and the markets. Even though we are getting closer to pre-recession GDP levels, this does not mean that the economy is back to normal," Kern said.

Mark Carney, the Bank's governor, said last month that the MPC would take "will not take risks with this recovery", and indicated that it was comfortable with the City's view that interest rates would not rise before the spring of 2015.

In the months leading up to the crisis, UK interest rates had hovered at around 5%, but in recent weeks MPC members have noted that when the Bank rate does eventually go up, it will only do so gradually and is likely to settle at around 2-3% and not the 4-5% level of the past.

Ultra-loose monetary policy has been credited with saving many homeowners from repossession and businesses from administration, but savers have watched the real value of their nest-eggs dwindle.

Interest rates have been left on hold for longer periods in the Bank's history – they remained at 2% from 1932 until 1951.

webTitle: Gina Rinehart says Australia is blessed but needs a good dose of Thatcherism

fields.standfirst: Mining magnate believes Margaret Thatcher made ‘courageous decisions in the interests of Britain, despite noisy detractors’
fields.body:
Australia needs a good dose of Thatcherism, mining magnate Gina Rinehart has written.

In a column for the Australian Resources and Investment magazine, Rinehart writes that Australians are “blessed” not living with war, terrorism or blizzards, and with bountiful natural resources.

Immigrants possibly chose to come here for these reasons, she said, for “a better life many believed not possible under socialist and far-left governments”.

Her remarks, which stress the importance of cutting public spending and rewarding hard work, seem to echo government lines from the prime minister and Joe Hockey that the large debt and deficit left by Labor meant “the age of entitlement was over”. However positive growth reports have recently contradicted the negativity.

Rinehart, who is Australia’s richest individual and earned her fortune from iron ore mining, painted former British prime minister Margaret Thatcher as an inspiration to Australia’s leaders.

“Europe and the free world sadly lost a courageous leader last year, Baroness Thatcher. Our political leaders are fortunate to have a leader they can emulate, a leader who well understood fundamental economic matters, critical for all countries and their standards of living.”

Thatcher, British Conservative party leader and PM from 1979 to 1990, died at the age of 87 last year. A polarising figure, she held fast to her conservative ideology and cut taxes and spending in the face of deep recession, nationwide protests, and a record 12% unemployment rate. Like Rinehart, Thatcher was closely associated with mines, although more with their demise, with 25 pits closed in 1985 alone.

Thatcher made “courageous decisions in the interests of Britain, despite the noisy detractors”, wrote Rinehart.

Rinehart predicted “forests and splinters” of “nasty twisted articles” from leftwing people “boiling with rage that I dare challenge their bottomless pit and belief that money doesn’t have to be earned before it is spent mentality”.

webTitle: Qantas bill to lift foreign ownership restrictions passes lower house

fields.standfirst: Labor warns bill could lead to the break-up of Australia’s national carrier as Coalition argues against governing ‘by nostalgia’
fields.body:
The lower house has passed a bill to remove Qantas’s foreign ownership restrictions, as the opposition warned of a break-up of the national carrier and ministers argued against governing “by nostalgia and sentiment”.

But the Abbott government’s proposed legislation still faces likely defeat in the Senate.

The deputy prime minister and transport minister, Warren Truss, presented his bill to “remove the regulatory handcuffs” to the house of representatives on Thursday morning.

The bill removes part three of the Qantas Sale Act – the part that imposes a 49% cap on the total foreign ownership of Qantas. The part to be abolished also caps ownership by a single foreign investor at 25% and ownership by foreign airlines at 35%. It also requires that facilities, including maintenance and catering, used by Qantas in the provision of international services are principally located in Australia.

But the government’s bill also amends a separate law – the Air Navigation Act – to include Qantas in the definition of an Australian international airline. This means Qantas’s international operations would remain subject to restrictions to access air traffic rights under Australia’s international air service agreements. The explanatory notes say this includes a requirement that “they are substantially owned and effectively controlled by Australian nationals”.

The opposition has predicted that the government’s bill could lead to the break-up of the national carrier into international and domestic arms, the latter of which could be majority foreign owned. The government is pursuing the bill despite the low chance of securing passage through either the current Senate or the new Senate, which sits from July. The bill is opposed by Labor, the Greens, key crossbench senators Nick Xenophon and John Madigan and the soon-to-be-influential Palmer United party.

The prime minister, Tony Abbott, said the lower house had “taken a big step towards liberating Qantas” from the shackles of the Qantas Sale Act.

In question time, the opposition asked Abbott whether he accepted Qantas’s enviable safety record was in no small part due to the professionalism, hard work, commitment and expertise of its Australian-based maintenance crews. Abbott said he was grateful to the workers responsible for Qantas’s “fine safety record” but it was reckless to suggest the Qantas Sale Act was responsible.

The Labor MP Michael Danby was forced to leave the chamber after he refused to withdraw his interjection which compared the safety of China Southern Airlines with that of Qantas.

During the earlier debate, Truss said the bill would allow aviation businesses in Australia to compete on an equal footing. It would “remove the regulatory handcuffs” that applied to Qantas but not to its competitors. Truss suggested the regulations held back Qantas and were reminiscent of the last century.

The opposition leader, Bill Shorten, said proposed changes to the Qantas Sale Act were a “mirage” because it would take time for the company to attract foreign capital and it did not address the company’s immediate issues.

Shorten said the treasurer, Joe Hockey, had recently strongly signalled his support for a debt guarantee for Qantas as part of an “ugly, messy process of which the government can take no pride”.

“You know you talk a lot about loving this country,” he told government members.

“You’re very quick to talk about patriotism but when it comes to a tough issue, a subtle issue, an issue which involves steering through, which doesn’t involve you standing at a parade and taking a salute – this is important – but when it comes to the tough issues of jobs, you go missing.”

The immigration minister, Scott Morrison, said he wanted Qantas to have a strong future but the opposition seemed to want to take Australia back to the pre-privatisation situation by suggesting greater taxpayer involvement in Qantas.

“I am a passionate advocate for Qantas but I am a realist as well and I know that a government that is serious cannot govern by nostalgia and sentiment. It cannot govern by emotion,” said Morrison, a former Tourism Australia chief.

“What Qantas needs is the ability to be able to work with equity partners … and we can’t keep these potential partners locked behind closed doors as the Qantas Sale Act does.”

Labor’s transport spokesman, Anthony Albanese, said his stance against majority foreign ownership of Qantas was based on a “cold, hard analysis of Australia’s economic interest” but also that the flying kangaroo was also “a source of pride” to Australians.

“Qantas is very different in terms of its corporate structure from Virgin. Virgin have the big owners; the three government-backed airlines and of course Virgin international through Richard Branson. Qantas’s ownership structure is very different,” he said.

Albanese said the impact of a Qantas break-up on the national interest should be taken “very seriously indeed”.

The government-dominated House of Representatives divided to vote 10 times in the space of less than four hours, including multiple procedural and gag motions.

Normally debate on a bill would be adjourned after being introduced by the relevant minister, unless urgent, but Labor called for an immediate debate. Truss initially rejected the idea but the leader of government business, Christopher Pyne, soon agreed that debate should be allowed.

Pyne said the government was “delighted” to move straight to debate as the lower house could pass the bill by lunchtime, shifting the matter to the Senate where any failure to pass the legislation would be Labor’s fault. After about two-and-a-half hours, Pyne began the process of shutting down debate and moving to a vote.

In the final division, MPs voted 83-53 to support the bill.

On Thursday the Senate launched a committee inquiry into options for government assistance to Qantas, including a debt guarantee or an equity stake, and the potential impact on jobs of the Coalition’s push to remove ownership restrictions. It is likely to call the Qantas chief executive, Alan Joyce, to give evidence.

Joyce last week announced plans to axe 5,000 full-time jobs and introduce wage freezes after posting an underlying before-tax loss of $252m for the last six months of 2013.
